question.body: The main difference between oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells is…

multiple_choice.choice: the type of myelin they produce
the number of axons a cell will be associated with
whether one or multiple cells are required to myelinate any axon
whether or not they insulate and facilitate signal propagation

response.feedback: Incorrect. They both produce the same kind of insulating myelin.
Correct. Oligodendrocytes are exclusively in the central nervous system and Schwann cells are exclusively in peripheral nervous system.

Incorrect. Although an oligodendrocyte’s processes will be wrapped around multiple axons and a Schwann cell can be wrapped around just one axon, a Schwann cell can also form around a bundle of axons, although it doesn’t form a tight myelin sheath.
Incorrect. In both central and peripheral nervous system it takes multiple cells to myelinate the length of an axon.
Incorrect. Both cells will form the myelin sheath that prevents ion leakage during neuron signal.
